bad.work: 'then She bore Pale desire' and 'Woe cried the muse'

title.reg: 'then She bore Pale desire' and 'Woe cried the muse'

titlestmt.title: "then She bore Pale desire" and "Woe cried the muse" : electronic edition
titlestmt.principal: Editors: Morris Eaves, University of Rochester; Robert Essick, University of California, Riverside; and Joseph Viscomi, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
titlestmt.sponsor: The Library of Congress, the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, and the University of Rochester

filedesc.extent: 1 XML file approx. 80 KB; 14 JPEG files ranging in size from 182KB to 1.3MB
filedesc.publicationstmt: Chapel Hill: Eaves, Essick, Viscomi; UNC Libraries August 2023
filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of a digital edition of four miscellaneous manuscript poems. Three of these four scraps of Blake’s legacy may have disappeared permanently were it not for the remarkable energy and devotion of the Gilchrists and Rossettis in tracing and publicizing what was left of “William Blake” by the second half of the nineteenth century. Not until a century later, in the 1980s, did the previously unknown “The Phoenix to Mrs Butts” resurface. Amazing things do happen.
Two prose poems, “then She bore Pale desire” and “Woe cried the muse,” in seven pages on four leaves, are likely Blake’s earliest surviving manuscript drafts (c. 1783). “then She bore Pale Desire” seems to begin in mid-course; whatever preceded the first line is missing.
In both style and content they resemble other early works such as “Fair Elenor” in Poetical Sketches (1783), relying heavily on popular late eighteenth century conventions such as the personification of abstractions—“Hate brooding in her Dismal den grew Pregnant & bore Scorn, & Slander” (“Pale Desire,” Object 5, lines 1-3)—alongside a few unmistakable anticipations of Blake’s later poetry, as in “the Nightly Blast that Blights the Infant Bud.” Compare “London,” Songs of Experience: “How the youthful harlots curse / Blasts the new born infants tear” (lines 15-16, Erdman page 27).
Four-beat couplets structure “A fairy leapt.” On the verso is a pencil sketch, The Infant Hercules Throttling the Serpents, though there is no obvious connection between the two. Fairies are not rare in Blake’s work. “So sang a Fairy mocking as he sat on a streak’d Tulip / . . . My Fairy sat upon the table, and dictated EUROPE” (Europe Plate iii, Erdman page 60). They seem to be associated with something like mischievous, potentially disruptive knowledge. Blake’s fairies fall taxonomically between angels and devils, emerging from a dimension somehow separate from the ghost world of history, mostly human, that he readily sketched on command for his young artist friends in his later life (collected as the Visionary Heads).
More carefully crafted, “The Phoenix to Mrs Butts”—the first Mrs. Butts—is designed in a manner reminiscent of Blake’s illuminated books, in this case close to the design of “A Little Girl Lost” from Songs of Innocence (1789) but composed as a kind of letter, and delivered by hand rather than by post. Beyond that, little is known of the circumstances that produced “The Phoenix.” It echoes the lexical imagery, meter (in this case, again, four-beat couplets), subject matter, and graphic design of, say, the Songs of Innocence and of Experience—and, yet again, a fairy:
The Fairy to my bosom flew
Weeping tears of morning dew
I said: Thou foolish whimpring thing
Is not that thy Fairy Ring . . .
Seem a Child & be a Child
And the Phoenix is beguild
All works in the Archive are accessible via the Table of Contents, which is accessible via the "sandwich" button at the right end of the banner. This drops down a second banner that identifies the categories of works in the Archive: Illuminated books, Commercial Book Illustrations, Separate Prints and Prints in Series, Drawings and Paintings, Manuscripts and Typographic Works. To further improve accessibility to the works, we've added a Table of Contents item, "All Works," which twice lists all of the works in the Archive without categorizing them according to genre or medium. One list puts the works in alphabetical order and the other in order of composition date. The latter list would of course be of interest to any Blake scholars mindful of the historical progression of Blake's works.
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill with the University of Rochester, the continuing support of the Library of Congress, and the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.

objtitle.title: *"then She bore Pale desire" and "Woe cried the muse"* This manuscript is sometimes collectively referred to as “The Passions” following W.M. Rossetti’s naming, description, and transcription of “then She bore Pale desire” in an article for *Monthly Magazine* in August 1903. See Erdman's "A Blake Manuscript in the Berg Collection: 'then She bore Pale desire' and 'Woe cried the muse,'" *Bulletin of the New York Public Library* (1958): 191-207.

objdescid.compdate: c. 1783 Due to several characteristics of the manuscript such as the handwriting, mythology, and metrical style, there is general agreement that the works were written in the 1770s and the 1780s. The date 1783 is "admittedly very tentative". See Bentley, *Writings* volume 2, page 1696.

objinfo.objorder: 1-7 Erdman notes that, despite both having torn left edges, leaves 1 and 4 were likely conjugate with other leaves rather than with each other. He further notes that as the strokes of both the “e” in “Shame” and the “l” in “Smoul” continue onto the adjacent leaf (our objects 4 and 5), the original conjunction of the second and third leaves is “unmistakable” (Erdman, "A Blake Manuscript in the Berg Collection: ’then She bore Pale desire' and ‘Woe cried the muse,’” *Bulletin of the New York Public Library* [1958]: 191-207). Both Bentley's (*Writings* volume 2, pages 869-874) and Erdman’s (446-448) transcriptions account for the apparent insertions indicated by Blake throughout the manuscript. We transcribe the manuscript as it appears, and discrepencies in the transcriptions by Erdman and Bentley are not noted here. For further reading, consult Erdman's "A Blake Manuscript in the Berg Collection: 'then She bore Pale desire' and 'Woe cried the muse,'" *Bulletin of the New York Public Library* (1958): 191-207.
objinfo.numberleaves: 4 The abrupt opening of "then She bore Pale desire" and the fact that the first word in the manuscript is not capitalized suggests there was once material preceding Object 1 that is now missing (Erdman, “A Blake Manuscript in the Berg Collection: ‘then She bore Pale desire’ and ‘Woe cried the muse,’” *Bulletin of the New York Public Library* [1958]: 191-207).
objinfo.medium:
pen and ink, pencil
Bentley and Erdman differentiate between the reddish brown ink, black ink, wide strokes, and fine strokes of the pen throughout the manuscript. Additionally, both Bentley and Erdman make note of the red ink slash marks and writing made by William Michael Rossetti.
objinfo.support: laid paper Laid paper with vertical chain lines 2.7 cm. apart.
objinfo.binding: loose The four leaves of this manuscript are mounted on larger leaves; the last leaf is pasted down and its verso is not visible.

provenance.name: New York Public Library
provenance.note: The early history of the manuscript is not known. W. M. Rossetti acquired it from John Defett Francis in or around 1876. In 1898, Rossetti sold the manuscript to Frank William Burgess for £12. However, while Burgess obtained the manuscript, he never paid for it, and after his death in 1899, his widow returned it to Rossetti. Rossetti's daughter, Helen Rossetti-Angeli, lent the manuscript to J. Sampson, and sold the work at Sotheby's on 27 March 1929 (lot 529, £440), where it was purchased by the dealer Walter T. Spencer. It was eventually acquired by Owen D. Young who, along with Dr. Albert A. Berg, presented it to the New York Public Library on 5 May 1941.

repository.department: Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection of English and American Literature

objnote.p: W. M. Rossetti, who acquired the manuscript around 1876, inserted slashes in red ink throughout the manuscript.
Blake left multiple letters uncrossed on this page. Bentley and Erdman normalize the spelling.
Bentley titles this portion of the manuscript (Objects 1-5) "then she bore Pale desire" as opposed to "then She bore Pale desire".

l.note: Bentley reads the deleted portion of this line as "& suspition Mixt" (*Writings* volume 2, page 872). Erdman, however, reads the final word in the line as "Mist" and suggests that Blake may have intended to write "Mistrust" (848n).
Blake wrote this line in pencil and wrote over "Emulation" in ink. A pencil line extends from the end of "Emulation" to the lines beginning on line 26.

objnote.p: There are a number of ink marks on the manuscript. Only those that obscure the text are noted.

lg.l:
Woe cried the muse tears Started at the Sound. Grief
perch't perched

upon my brow and thought

mean I cried. when all around. Summer hath

ere ever
while so fair, and now they Erdman reads the comma after "fair" as a period (448).
fall & beg the Skies will weep. a Day like this laid Elfrid
in the Dust. Sweet Elfrid fairer than the Beaming Sun

O Soon cut off
ith in the morning of her days,
twas it was the Bentley reads "ith" as "i th" (*Writings* volume 2, page 873). Erdman reads a period after "days" (448).

Rude thunder Stroke that
Closd Closed her Eyes,Erdman reads the comma after "Eyes" as a period (448). and laid
her lilied Beauties on the Green, The dance was broke

the Circle just Begun the flower was
Pluckd Plucked &
yet it was not blown; But What art thou! I Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 874) and Erdman (448) read "What" as "what". Erdman reads the semicolon after "blown" as a period (448).

could no more. Bentley reads the period after "more" as a comma (*Writings* volume 2, page 874). till mute attention Struck my
trem trembling
blingtrembling Ear. It Spoke I come my friend to take my

last farewell.
Sunk by. the hand of Death in
Watry Watery tombBentley reads a comma after "farewell" and omits the period after "by" (*Writings* volume 2, page 874). Erdman reads "Watry" as "Wat'ry" (448).

l.note: Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 874) and Erdman (849n) read the deletion as "ruffling".

lg.l: Oer Over yonder ^ lake. wh liCorse Erdman reads the deleted portion of this line as "while ?living clay cold corpse Corse" (849n). Bentley reads the deletion as "while his... Clay Cold Corpse Corse" (*Writings* volume 2, page 874).
the winds their Sad complainings bear, for. ConradeComrade lost Erdman reads "the" as "The" and the comma after "bear" as a period (448).
untimely lost thy ConradeComrade once. When living thee I

lovd. loved.
ev'n even unto Death now Dead. I'll guard thee from Bentley omits the period after "lovd" (*Writings* volume 2, page 874). Erdman reads "I'll" as "Ill" (448).
approaching ill. Bentley reads the period after "ill" as a comma (*Writings* volume 2, page 874). farewell my time is gone, it Said
no more. but vanished. from my Sight

objnote.p: W. M. Rossetti, who acquired the manuscript around 1876, inserted slashes in red ink throughout the manuscript.

Rossetti makes two notes in red ink at the bottom lefthand corner of this object. The first reads "N. B. The words at the head of this page shd. come in after the mark X on the 4th. page of the M.S". The second reads "The words 'And Shame bore Honour' to come in after the mark A on 4th. page."

lg.l: x She brings humility to man take her She Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 871) and Erdman (447) read "brings" with certainty. Lines 1-7 after the "X" on this Object are marked for insertion after the words "Sweet Contemplation" on Object 4 with a corresponding "X". There is an ambiguous mark above, and potentially connected to, the "t" of "take". Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 871) and Erdman (447) read "take" as "Take".
Says & wear her in thine heart lord of thy Selfthyself
thou then art lord of all, humility, herThe phrase "humility, her Daughter," in lines 3 and 5 is partially outlined.Bentley reads the comma after "all" as a period (*Writings* volume 2, page 871).

Daughter, TisIt is Contemplation teacheth knowldThe last word in this line is presumably an abbreviation of "knowledge". Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 871) reads the word as "knowled[ge]" and Erdman (447) reads "knowledge" with certainty.
truly how to know- &c &c

l.add: & Policy doth dwell wth her by whom she
l.note: Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 873n) and Erdman (448) read the abbreviated and superscripted "wth" as "with".

lg.l: Conceit &^ Mistrust & Suspition |
by. Shame She had a Son calldcalledBentley omits the period after "by" (*Writings* volume 2, page 873n).
HonourHonor, who bore Revenge,Bentley omits the comma after "Honour" and reads the comma after "Revenge" as a period (*Writings* volume 2, page 873n). Then
Self love, bore a Daughter calledThe words "Self love" are crossed through three times.Bentley reads "called" as "Called" (*Writings* volume 2, page 873n).
Emulation. who. married, honourBentley omits the comma after "married" (*Writings* volume 2, page 873n).
these follow her around the World

AthenAnd Shame bore honourhonor & made "And" appears to be overwritten in ink. Lines 16-17 after the "A" on this Object are marked for insertion after the words "She brought forth Rage" with a corresponding "A" on Object 4. Bentley notes an additional possible reading based on the pencil mark connecting lines 9 and 16 (*Writings* volume 2, page 873n).
league with Pride
swift as the Nightly Blast that Blights the InfantBentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 874) and Erdman (448) read the conjectural "swift" with certainty.
